newsitem.title: UK: Russia gets high speculative grade credit ratings.
newsitem.headline: Russia gets high speculative grade credit ratings.

text.p: Russia's foreign currency debt received high speculative grade ratings on Monday but major credit agencies sounded alarm bells about the country's leadership and legal systems and short economic track record.
Moody's Investors Service said it assigned a Ba2 sovereign ceiling for ratings on long-term foreign currency bonds and notes of issuers domiciled in Russia.
Standard & Poor's assigned a BB minus long-term rating and IBCA, the European rating agency, rated it BB plus long-term.

The ratings from all three agencies fell below the "investment grade" threshold, although Russia has received a more favourable rating than Brazil, one of the world's largest emerging market economies. Moody's rates Brazil B1.

The ratings have been long awaited in international markets as Russia prepared to issue its first Eurobond. The news pushed prices of Russian "MinFin" bonds sharply higher as even lower ratings had been expected.

The Moody's rating pegs Russia as a credit risk of similar standing to countries such as Mexico, Venezuela and the Philippines, and puts it below neighbour the Czech republic, which has an investment grade rating of Baa1.
"Russian political uncertainties have hampered economic performance and slowed the transition to a more efficient market economy," Moody's said.
It said that if the current president and government were replaced in a future election, all likely successors would be more expansionary and nationalistic in their economic approach.

S&P also said, "President Yeltsin's current illness highlights the risk that changes at the top may, at least for a time, halt the reform process and undermine the authorities' ability to pursue prudent and consistent economic policies."
But both agencies said there was support in Russia for some of the results of economic reform.
"During the past two years, tight fiscal and monetary policies have yielded progressively better results on inflation, monetary growth, and the consolidated budget deficit," Moody's said.
S&P said strong international backing for Russia's transformation to a market-based economy should continue in the medium term.
S&P, which also said the outlook on the long-term rating was stable, said other key constraining factors were:
-- the government's short economic management track record and, especially, the political and administrative difficulties it faces raising tax revenues,
-- a weak legal system, including lax enforcement that continues to foster widespread corruption, discourages foreign investment, and acts as a drag on overall economic activity.
IBCA said that on the plus side, the rating was underpinned by strong growth in export receipts from oil and gas, which had continued throughout the transition slump.
"Russia also benefits from relatively low external debt ratios despite the decision to assume all the external debt of the former Soviet Union," IBCA said.
Russia received short-term ratings of Not Prime from Moody's and B from S&P and IBCA.
